awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Preparing Urban Milwaukee for Pathways in Computer Science
awd_abstract_narration:
Wisconsin faces increasingly inequitable access to Computer Science (CS) content in schools. Affluent suburban schools add courses, such as CS Principles (CSP), at a record rate. Schools with fewer resources have little or no CS offerings and see meager access diminished as scarce while CS teachers are lured away to industry and the suburbs. Marquette University and The Learning Partnership have already made significant inroads in expanding Wisconsin's CS professional development opportunities for teachers. Prior work over the last five years has provided CS Professional Development to over 1,850 K-5 teachers, reaching over 67,000 school children. Careful assessment will allow the team to explore deeper questions about how prior CS exposure effects students later in the CS pathway, why execution of CS initiatives are so unevenly effective in different parts of the city, and how to strengthen and expand a pathway in a dynamic urban school system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
Overview

The PUMP-CS Research-Practitioner Partnership (RPP) among Milwaukee Public Schools (MPS), Marquette University and The Learning Partnership has planted many vital seeds of CS access in the more than 135 separate schools across MPS. PUMP-CS is focused on developing a systemic, cohesive, PK-12 CS pathway that can provide high-quality courses and experiences across the breadth of MPS school contexts. This pathway must be robust in a school district with ubiquitous school choice, shrinking enrollment, confounding feeder school relationships, deep socioeconomic inequalities, and one of the highest levels of racial segregation in the nation. As part of this effort, Marquette led the co-design of evidence-based practices with MPS, and The Learning Partnership investigated the extent to which these practices led to their intended outcomes. 

Intellectual Merit 

PUMP-CS supported the expansion of CS opportunities in MPS through the enactment of a pathways of high-quality CS curriculum supported by professional development. In grades K-5, teachers were trained to implement Code.org Computer Science Fundamentals (CSF). In grades 6-8, teachers were trained to implement Code.org Computer Science Discoveries (CSD). In high school, teachers were trained to implement Exploring Computer Science (ECS) as well as Code.org AP Computer Science Principles (CSP). Throughout the life of PUMP-CS, the middle school CSD proved to be a critical juncture point for the CS pathway. Middle school is the first time students begin taking separate classes for the different subject areas. It became challenging for schools to find room in the curriculum to offer a separate class on computer science. CSD was often implemented as an elective as part of “specials” classes, like a STEM class, or integrated into math and science classes. 

PUMP-CS conducted a series of investigations to better articulate this problem of practice at this key juncture point. Through interviews with principals at schools with teachers who participated in CSD training, but were not implementing CSD, the principals stressed the importance of computer science for the students’ futures. However, the principals reported that the school district did not provide additional funding for CS and that there was limited time in the curriculum to add CS. The principals indicated that they encouraged their teachers to participate in the CSD professional development so that they had the capacity to offer CS if and when the district increases its support for CS.

In those schools that offered CSD, PUMP-CS also explored the opportunities and barriers that teachers faced in implementing CSD after their initial training. Some teachers expressed that the initial weeklong professional development was not sufficient to prepare them to teach CSD. Most of the teachers participating in the CSD professional development did not have a CS background and they did not feel that the workshop focused sufficiently on the content of CS that would be needed to teach the class. In addition, teachers felt that they needed additional support around lesson planning to understand how best to implement CSD. To support the need for implementation guidance, PUMP-CS offered monthly online professional learning community (PLC) meetings. The PLCs offered break-out rooms that allowed teachers to choose which area they needed assistance with– teachers liked this freedom. Teachers liked how in the PLCs, time was used to demonstrate new lessons, subjects, and ideas, which was a desire of teachers who participated in the implementation study. 

We investigated teachers’ understanding and comfort with the CSD program model to identify their content knowledge needs.Recognizing that most teachers preparing to teach CSD will not have a CS background and recognizing that a weeklong workshop will not sufficiently provide teachers with the content knowledge needed, Code.org designed the educational materials to be taught through a Lead Learner Model. The activities in CSD are inquiry-based and are designed for teachers to learn the content alongside the students. Within the Lead Learner Model, teachers can model for the students how to be a learner of CS. Through interviews with teachers, it was discovered that teachers generally felt comfortable with the inquiry-based approach of CSD. However, the expectations of the Lead Learner Model were not clearly articulated in the workshops. Despite the lack of explicit orientation to the Lead Learner model, we found that teachers who already had an orientation to student inquiry were able to adapt to the Lead Learner Model and to persist in teaching CSD over time. 

Broader Impacts

Despite these limitations, 289 teachers implemented CSF, CSD, or CSP from the inception of PUMP-CS through the 2022-23 school year. Using learning analytics, it was found that those students who achieved success in their lessons on the first try or those that gave up after not achieving success on the first try were less likely to succeed in the class. In contrast, the students that were most successful in their CS courses were those that persisted despite having initial challenges with the materials. 


Last Modified: 02/24/2025
Modified by: Steven M McGee

Overview

As part of this effort, Marquette led the co-design of evidence-based practices with MPS, and The Learning Partnership investigated the extent to which these practices led to their intended outcomes.

Middle school is the first time students begin taking separate classes for the different subject areas. CSD was often implemented as an elective as part of specials classes, like a STEM class, or integrated into math and science classes.


PUMP-CS conducted a series of investigations to better articulate this problem of practice at this key juncture point. Through interviews with principals at schools with teachers who participated in CSD training, but were not implementing CSD, the principals stressed the importance of computer science for the students futures. Despite these limitations, 289 teachers implemented CSF, CSD, or CSP from the inception of PUMP-CS through the 2022-23 school year. Using learning analytics, it was found that those students who achieved success in their lessons on the first try or those that gave up after not achieving success on the first try were less likely to succeed in the class. In contrast, the students that were most successful in their CS courses were those that persisted despite having initial challenges with the materials.					Last Modified: 02/24/2025
